results.headline: A Barrel of Red Herrings and a Heap of Shady Men

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gone

results.summary_short: An abduction that may or may not have happened and a disappearing sister are enough to push a spooked young woman over the edge in “Gone.”

results.headline: Beguiled by a Nymph So Nimble

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Fairy

results.summary_short: “The Fairy” asks the question: What to do when a shoeless creature bursts into your hotel and says she’ll grant you three wishes?

results.headline: Striking an Elvis Pose Behind the Iron Curtain

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hipsters

results.summary_short: The Russian musical “Hipsters” imagines 1955 Moscow as a place where the gray-faced majority stalked rebels who could be found in underground lairs.

results.headline: Albanian Feud’s Fallout

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Forgiveness of Blood

results.summary_short: Joshua Marston’s new film, “The Forgiveness of Blood,” looks at the impact of a deadly feud in an Albanian village.

results.headline: Good Vibrations for All; Clothing Is Optional

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wanderlust

results.summary_short: David Wain’s “Wanderlust” offers a commune with the comforts of hippie days to Jennifer Aniston and Paul Rudd, on the run from economic ruin.

results.headline: Real Men Fight Real Wars and an Occasional Actor

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Act of Valor

results.summary_short: In “Act of Valor” real members of the Navy SEALs show off what they do in a concocted story, complete with a kidnapped C.I.A. officer and a hook-nosed villain.

results.headline: Sometimes Cooler Heads Don’t Prevail

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance 3D

results.summary_short: “Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance” stars Nicolas Cage in a sequel to the 2007 film.

results.headline: In Realm of the Tiny, Standing Up to the Big

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Secret World of Arrietty

results.summary_short: “The Secret World of Arrietty,” an animated children’s film from Studio Ghibli, has the small making wonderfully do in a world inhabited by, and made for, the big.

results.headline: A Story Too Feel-Good for Fiction

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Undefeated

results.summary_short: For “Undefeated,” the directors Dan Lindsay and T. J. Martin spent a year following a poor black Memphis football team and the white coaches who mentored him.

results.headline: Buddy C.I.A. Officers Trade Guns for Roses

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This Means War

results.summary_short: In “This Means War,” Tom Hardy and Chris Pine play C.I.A. officers who are best friends until they fall for the same woman (Reese Witherspoon).

results.headline: Lofty Violin, Lowly Ambitions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thin Ice

results.summary_short: “Thin Ice,” a version of a film shown at Sundance last year, blends low-key comedy with violence and mayhem.

results.headline: A Seal Hunt, a Secret and a Strained Bond

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of On the Ice

results.summary_short: In “On the Ice,” three Alaskan teenagers head out on a seal hunt and only two return, bearing the burden of a secret that strains bonds far deeper than those of the two survivors.

results.headline: Memory’s Intrusions Cloud a Sunny Idyll

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jess + Moss

results.summary_short: “Jess + Moss,” directed by Clay Jeter, is a rural childhood idyll set on a Kentucky tobacco farm.

results.headline: Temperamental Cat Goes AWOL in a Land Gripped by War Fever

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cirkus Columbia

results.summary_short: Set in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Danis Tanovic’s “Cirkus Columbia” is a scalding black comedy about the insanity of war.

results.headline: A Raging Man, Ruled and Ruined by an Excess of Testosterone

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bullhead

results.summary_short: “Bullhead” is the story of a slightly misshapen lug who runs a cattle farm in Limburg, in the Flemish region of Belgium, and who is addicted to anabolic steroids.

results.headline: Through the Eyes of a Predator Acting Like a Parent

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Michael

results.summary_short: “Michael” puts the viewer in the shoes of the perpetrator and, to a lesser degree, his captive, much of whose relationship resembles a father-son bond.

results.headline: Awash in Capitalism, a Changing Earth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Forgotten Space

results.summary_short: In “The Forgotten Space,” Noël Burch and Allan Sekula explore the pared-down economy of the shipping industry.

results.headline: After Mumbai, Letting His Socks Down in Las Vegas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ek Main Aur Ekk Tu

results.summary_short: “Ek Main aur Ekk Tu” is a Bollywood comedy about an uptight architect and a free-spirited hairstylist trying to make it in Las Vegas.

results.headline: Facing the Abyss With Boiled Potatoes and Plum Brandy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Turin Horse

results.summary_short: The Hungarian director Bela Tarr’s black-and-white film “The Turin Horse” (he has said it’s last) is a thorough and systematic statement of intellectual despair.

results.headline: She’s Angry, and He’s Lost: Sort of Perfect Together

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dish & The Spoon

results.summary_short: Alison Bagnall’s film “The Dish & the Spoon” follows the relationship between a woman upset by her husband’s infidelity and a British teenager.
